channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: PHOTOS: A drone's eye view of 'foodscapes,' from cattle to soybeans to shrimp
item.description: Traveling to 36 countries and 5 oceans, George Steinmetz (and his drones) take us on a food tour in his new book Feed the Planet:  A Photographic Journey to the World's Food.
item.content:encoded:
Traveling to 36 countries and 5 oceans, George Steinmetz (and his drones) take us on a food tour in his new book Feed the Planet:  A Photographic Journey to the World's Food.

(Image credit: George Steinmetz)
item.dc:creator: Diane Cole

item.title: After turkey, take a trot. A little post-meal walk can be a big boost for health
item.description: Among the latest health hacks to go viral on TikTok is the idea of short post-dinner "fart walk" to aid digestion. Turns out, the science on this trend is solid, and so are the health benefits.
item.content:encoded:
Among the latest health hacks to go viral on TikTok is the idea of short post-dinner "fart walk" to aid digestion. Turns out, the science on this trend is solid, and so are the health benefits.

(Image credit: Annie Otzen)
item.dc:creator: Maria Godoy

item.title: Pakistan ends lockdown of its capital after dispersing Imran Khan supporters
item.description: The operation came hours after thousands of Khan supporters broke through a barrier of shipping containers blocking off Islamabad and clashed with security forces.
item.content:encoded:
The operation came hours after thousands of Khan supporters broke through a barrier of shipping containers blocking off Islamabad and clashed with security forces.

(Image credit: Anjum Naveed)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Brazil police report: Bolsonaro planned and participated in a 2022 coup plot
item.description: The document describe the former president as one of the key leaders of the plot, and not a mere observer.
item.content:encoded:
The document describe the former president as one of the key leaders of the plot, and not a mere observer.

(Image credit: Eraldo Peres)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Trump turns to critic of COVID mandates to run NIH
item.description: Dr. Jay Bhattacharya, a Stanford health researcher, is in line to lead the National Institutes of Health. Early in the pandemic he argued against lockdowns and focusing on people at highest risk.
item.content:encoded:
Dr. Jay Bhattacharya, a Stanford health researcher, is in line to lead the National Institutes of Health. Early in the pandemic he argued against lockdowns and focusing on people at highest risk.

(Image credit: Tom Williams/CQ-Roll Call)
item.dc:creator: Rob Stein

item.title: A Ceasefire Between Israel and Hezbollah in Lebanon
item.description:
Israel has agreed to a ceasefire with the militant group Hezbollah in Lebanon that hopes to bring an end to 13 months of fighting which has uprooted masses of civilians on both sides, and left immense destruction. We hear from NPR reporters on both sides of the conflict.

Support NPR and get sponsor-free episodes of State of the World. Sign up for NPR+ at plus.npr.org
Or donate to NPR this Giving Tuesday at donate.npr.org
item.content:encoded:
Israel has agreed to a ceasefire with the militant group Hezbollah in Lebanon that hopes to bring an end to 13 months of fighting which has uprooted masses of civilians on both sides, and left immense destruction. We hear from NPR reporters on both sides of the conflict.

Support NPR and get sponsor-free episodes of State of the World. Sign up for NPR+ at plus.npr.org

item.dc:creator: Daniel Estrin

item.title: Trump team signs a key transition agreement with Biden White House
item.description: This is one of two agreements that was supposed to have been signed by Oct. 1. The Trump team has decided to forgo the second one, saying it has its own systems in place.
item.content:encoded:
This is one of two agreements that was supposed to have been signed by Oct. 1. The Trump team has decided to forgo the second one, saying it has its own systems in place.

(Image credit: Roberto Schmidt)
item.dc:creator: Tamara Keith

item.title: Trump's tariffs may be targeted at others -- but they could impact you too
item.description: President-elect Donald Trump threatened to slap hefty tariffs on China, Canada and Mexico. Those tariffs would hurt America too — if they are carried out.
item.content:encoded:
President-elect Donald Trump threatened to slap hefty tariffs on China, Canada and Mexico. Those tariffs would hurt America too — if they are carried out.

(Image credit: Ulises Ruiz)
item.dc:creator: Scott Horsley

item.title: With a record number of international students in the U.S., Trump brings uncertainty
item.description: Some schools and international students in the U.S. worry about what's to come in the incoming Trump administration. Meanwhile, a new report finds more international students in the U.S. than ever.
item.content:encoded:
Some schools and international students in the U.S. worry about what's to come in the incoming Trump administration. Meanwhile, a new report finds more international students in the U.S. than ever.

(Image credit: Justin Sullivan)
item.dc:creator: Juliana Kim

item.title: Beer before liquor? Busting 6 popular myths about hangovers
item.description: People have a lot of opinions about how to cure a hangover. Are any of them true? Medical experts dispel common misconceptions about the effects of drinking too much alcohol.
item.content:encoded:
People have a lot of opinions about how to cure a hangover. Are any of them true? Medical experts dispel common misconceptions about the effects of drinking too much alcohol.

(Image credit: Photo illustration by Becky Harlan)
item.dc:creator: Andee Tagle
